determiner.description: An unspecified amount or number of.
examples: I made some money running errands
he played some records for me

determiner.description: Used to refer to someone or something that is unknown or unspecified.
examples: I was talking to some journalist the other day
he's in some kind of trouble
some thirty different languages are spoken

determiner.description: A considerable amount or number of.
examples: I've known you for some years now

determiner.description: At least a small amount or number of.
examples: he liked some music but generally wasn't musical

pronoun.description: An unspecified number or amount of people or things.
examples: here are some of our suggestions
if you want whiskey I'll give you some

pronoun.description: At least a small amount or number of people or things.

examples: when you get to the majors, the rules change some

phrases: we got our money's worth and then some
I've put on all the weight I lost during last year's diet, and then some.
Although I have enough offprints to meet the requests I've had, and then some, it will take me a while to process them all.
As far as the fair share statement goes, Minnesota has gotten its fair share and then some.
Now the sun will supply enough light to illuminate half the world at one sitting, so there's plenty of power and then some.
origin: Old English sum, of Germanic origin, from an Indo-European root shared by Greek hamōs somehow and Sanskrit sama any, every.
